Award.AwardTitle: LRT 2015: Junior and Under-Represented Researcher Participation Support. Workshop at the University of Washington's Husky Union Building (HUB).
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support for junior and under-represented researchers to participate in the Fifth Low Radioactivity Techniques (LRT) Workshop at the University of Washington's Husky Union Building (HUB) on March 18-20, 2015.

This workshop has a particular focus on early career scientists, graduate students and under-represented researchers. The workshop is important in the education of such young scientists not only because of the lectures they listen to, but also because they can directly communicate with the more experienced scientists who are the lecturers.

The LRT Workshop is focused on methods and techniques to enhance and extend radiometric measurement techniques and rare event searches that could be limited in sensitivity due to the presence of interfering background radioactivity that is ubiquitous and/or naturally occurring. The workshop science topics include dark matter, solar neutrinos, double-beta decay, and long half-life phenomena.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the University of Washington co-hosted the fifth Low Radioactivity Techniques (LRT) Workshop at the University of Washington’s Husky Union Building (HUB) on March 18-20, 2015. This was the most well attended LRT Workshop to date, showing the growth in need and interest in this research area.

The LRT Workshop is focused on methods and techniques to enhance and extend radiometric measurement techniques and rare event searches that could be limited in sensitivity due to the presence of interfering background radioactivity that is ubiquitous and/or naturally occurring. The LRT workshop science topics include dark matter, solar neutrinos, double-beta decay, and long half-life phenomena. This conference’s wide scope includes all aspects of the development of low background detectors and techniques. The intention is to foster and continue the collaboration and resource sharing required for new generations of detectors to be developed at underground facilities. The workshop brings together experts in low radioactivity materials and techniques, a fundamental aspect of rare event searches.

The National Science Foundation and W-IE-NE-R provided support to defray the cost of attendance for junior and under-represented researchers. An application process was announced through the American Physical Society’s Division of Particles and Fields email distribution list, the LRT 2015 website, and through the LRT International Science Organizing Committee. Applicants submitted a short (~1 page) description of their research area of interest and a brief statement as to how the support award would benefit their careers, research, and development. This process resulted in the acceptance of the seven participants who applied for support. Unfortunately one of the supported participants was unable to secure a travel visa to the United States and was unable to attend.

The junior and under-represented researchers were supported via Workshop Agreements that provided for expenses related to three nights of lodging and registration. The W-IE-NE-R portion of the support was applied to the cost of the Workshop dinner for all of the supported participants so they would have the opportunity to continue networking and building relationships with others attending the LRT Workshop.
